Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 03:59PM inspiewriter wrote: Just found this on the Juzo site:  Can I use lotions and creams with your garments?  It’s perfectly safe to use lotions and creams with a Juzo brand compression garments because all Juzo garments are Latex Free. This is especially important for people with lymphedema since daily skin care and moisturizer is so important. Lotions and ointments breakdown garments made out of natural rubber.     So I have emailed them to be sure they include suncreen in "lotions."

Mine is mild and for a few years I got away with not wearing daily sleeve/glove, but now, even if I feel it's not really needed I wear anyway for several reasons. --my LE arm is still larger and whiter than the other. --I feel the garments protect me is some ways, like from a papercut. And from other people bumping me--they notice the garments and seem to steer clear.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 02:38AM inspiewriter wrote: It does get annoying. But I find myself often asking other people I meet what they did to their own wrapped/bandaged/casted body parts--I feel I am being a caring person. It's also because I assume it's due to an injury--would never dream of asking if I thought I was inquiring about something like bc!  Once a car salesman about my compression sleeve--and then told me he'd worn one for years after a severe burn. I don't ever tell them b/c, if it's a stranger. If they ask "Do you have carpal tunnel?" I say "something like that." Sometimes my dh speaks up and tells them "it's old age" and that shuts them up. Once a waitress got so insistent and I ended up telling her everything--and was pretty annoyed with her. I think she was sorry she asked.   Sometimes I just say "I have edema" and leave it at that. Let them look it up if they like. Getting ready to go run karaoke with my hubby at a graduation party today--and I know I will get the question several times. *sigh*

Posts.Title: Question mssuzi01 inspiewriter

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 04:22PM inspiewriter wrote: I have been full-wrapping at night (instead of using my tubular sleeve).  Sleeve and glove most of the day. I could probably go without these in the winter months but I am afraid of re-swelling. Try to rebound a few minutes morning and evening. Try to do the massage and exercises at least every other day. Have started drying and washing in the massage direction, per info I got here on this forum. Try not to lift anything heavy. Use cuticle cream on my nails several nights a week to prevent hangnails. Do the abdominal breathing for a few minutes every time I think of it.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 08:44AM inspiewriter wrote: I had an exc. biopsy after being advised to wait several months. Finally it was driving me nuts and I had it done, got the results and ended up with 2 more surgeries.  Less than a year later I had LE from the lymph nodes removed. I have heard that you can get LE from ANY type of surgery (or trauma to the body) but it doesn't sound like yours is high risk. If you want peace of mind, have the biopsy done. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Is It Possible To Get Lymphedema From An Excisional Biopsy? Kim32 inspiewriter
